content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would approach this game strategically to maximize my earnings over the 75 rounds. The best strategy here is to use something called Tit-for-Tat, which is a popular strategy in repeated games.

In Tit-for-Tat, you start by cooperating (picking R) and then mimic your opponent's previous move in the next round. If my opponent picks R first, I will also pick R. However, if they pick B first, I will pick B in the following round to punish them for not cooperating, but then return to cooperation in the third round (picking R again).

The reasoning behind this is that in a repeated game, it's beneficial to maintain a cooperative relationship as much as possible. If you always cooperate (pick R), you will earn 12$ every time your opponent chooses B. But if your opponent starts with B, punishing them by also picking B will encourage them to switch to cooperation in the next round.

After considering this strategy, I would choose R as my initial move, so my choice is {R}. However, remember that the success of this strategy depends on both players following the Tit-for-Tat rule. If the other player does not reciprocate and starts cooperating, I will continue to cooperate (picking R) in subsequent rounds to maximize my earnings.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent did not cooperate in the first round, I will now pick B to punish them for their non-cooperative move and increase the likelihood of them switching to cooperation in the next round. So, my choice for the next round is {B}. This strategy follows the Tit-for-Tat rule where you start by cooperating (picking R), but then mimic your opponent's previous move in the next round. In this case, since my opponent picked B first, I will pick B to encourage them to cooperate in the following rounds.

By picking R in this round, I hope that my opponent will continue to cooperate and pick R in the following rounds as well.
